content: Well done! How exactly are you using normal JS inside KA? I have been unable to use even simple variable declarations (like let or const). And how are you calling env or the '=>' syntax? I cannot seem to use these without the program throwing an error.
sandbox break
I am unfamiliar with that term. Although I've been able to use JS in a <script> tag in HTML.
the pjs environment runs in a sandbox. i used an exploit to break out of the sandbox and run js code pretty much directly in the frame
Ah, did you use JSON? What kind of exploit did you use?
i used an exploit that as far as i know i came up with, using prototype pollution on the PJSCodeInjector class
Are you polluting the PJSCodeInjector with the ___proto___ property?
nah. i guess it's not technically prototype pollution then. I'm just modifying PJSCodeInjector.prototype since i have access to the class directly
Ah, that makes sense. So you are simply modifying the PJSCodeInjector class within the PJS sandbox, thus breaking out of the constraints of the sandbox itself, and then running your own code?
yeah. if you want to take a look i posted my code on my github @nim-ka
what is your reprository called?
"kamusicy"
which file would contain the sandbox break code?
build.sh line 211
Thank you! This code is fascinating. I've never considered using KA's own classes to alter their constrictions on JS.
400 up lines of *HI's are pretty impressive!

thanks. i'm not the first to do a sandbox break like this though. have to admit that when i was a kid and was more active on KA i was aware of this kind of exploit but was very scared off having to go off KA and look at actual code 😬
I felt the same way when I was younger! Real-life code can be quite intimidating as opposed to PJS.

It's really cool how you made it show code that actually doesn't do anything and then hide the actual code, but I don't think that is the purpose of Khan Academy, it's for learning and sharing talent (though I guess this is talent).

I do have a question, though... did you write the music? Or did you just have it play a song that you found?

i wrote the music. actually i have another program called musicy2 where i have more tracks. one of them is some version of among us music and one is some luigi's mansion thing i arranged but the rest is Original
That's awesome! I've never been able to write my own music... I can get a start, but then I get stuck with that
thanks lol. i kind of have the same problem, i wish i could flesh out the musical ideas i make more
I could listen to this forever...

I am not only the first to comment, but also very confused.

How are there only like 4 lines of code?
magic
For a while there's a bunch of "hi"s and some random letters + numbers. I'm SO confused!
correct that is indeed what happens when the program starts
And I just realized, it plays when you LEAVE KHAN ACADEMY. How?? I have never seen another program that runs, even when another tab is entered. What kind of sorcery is this!
really? that shouldn't be happening. on my browser i know it plays like a note maybe after leaving sometimes
or do you just mean switching tabs
switching tabs
yeah ok makes sense
Also like, what's going on here? Did you make the visualizer, and how are you using custom sounds? Also, how did this only get two votes?

i made the visualizer and everything. all the sounds are generated raw from the waveform in javascript and played using webaudio. the music tracks are coded in a custom scripting language similar to midi but worse

this has(had) only 2 votes because i dont care about votes and nobody follows my profile lol. i moved on from KA a long time ago

im surprised people are even voting this up tbh
Bro, you're seriously skilled
thanks

It's actually illegal code. This is the code decrypted and fetched from the api :
https://www.khanacademy.org/computer-programming/highly-illegal-code/5820212592033792
vexcess's program links back to this one...
Exactly... Vexcess took the code from the API
That's an illegal comment! I'm going to flag you for advertising! (not)
Is it actually illegal or something else?
Yeah, only webpages are allowed to play audio tones.
I think what blueleaf is trying to say is: "Are the police going to arrest you for making this program?".
No, but you'll get banned. First off, it uses window post requests to hide the code. That's a biggie. I know this because I purposely used a slow computer.

Let's review KA guidelines. 
```
Project guidelines
Projects should reflect the strides you’ve made in your coding journey, and beginners are always welcome to flex their creative muscles here! However, there are some basic rules to keep in mind as you do this.

If a project or discussion post falls into one of the following disallowed criteria, a Guardian may hide it from the "hot" list and/or public view entirely. Learners who persistently break these rules may also get banned from community activity. Projects that spur discussions that distract from learning about computer programming and coding may also get hidden.
```
Notice that it says a guardian _may_ hide it.
From my experience here, many guardians will ignore disallowed functionality when it is used in a creative and non-harmful way.

:P Good point! I usually just tend to stick on the literal side of things. To be safe, you probably shouldn't do it. The only thing it can be used for is music-based programs, and someone already made an editor lol.
i know only webpages are technically allowed to play webaudio but webpage js is just massively inconvenient and there's no sandbox break in webpages afaik sooooo
honestly if it's allowed on webpages i see no issue with me doing it in pjs. the pjs coding environment is just superior in every way
the only iffy thing for me is hiding the code. but i only did that because i don't want to be accused of spreading sandbox break exploits lol

1. That is wrong lol. Webpage JS is better in every way, but that's not the point of my argument. 
2. Off-topic argument. You are putting up reasons why the rule already set in place shouldn't exist. You should be instead trying to prove that your program uses no disallowed functionality. 
3. 99% sure "sandbox break exploits" are against the Guidelines. If you got this from Squishy, that confirms my suspicions with the simple fact that he was banned a year or two ago for this kind of activity.
4. Stop spamming people with useless arguments. Also, "iffy" is still wrong. Stop hiding the code, and then I can check for disallowed functionality.

1. dude i'm just saying i prefer the pjs environment for various reasons. it's just always going to be more lightweight
2. i wasnt making an argument lol
3. what i got from squishy was the idea to make something with webaudio
4. the code has been published on my github @nim-ka under the repo "kamusicy". either way, you already *have* the link to the program vexcess made where they got the code soooo
man i miss ka bullet point arguments so much. they tickle my autism bone so well

1. Forgive my ignorance but isn't PJS just HTML-JS with a _really_ old version of p5.js and a ton of overhead?

5. In HTML if you use a script tag with `type = ""`, you can use es8. Can you do that in PJS?
I think PJS and p5.js are technically separate things — they just have a lot in common with Processing.

the pjs environment does not have significantly more overhead than the webpage environment

also yes if you do a sandbox break like i did you can use whatever es your browser supports
And this is where the argument has left everything I know about coding. Basically, I am noob.

what you are doing is completely allowed in HTML programs, but not allowed in PJS programs. And it seems a lot of people don't like you doing it in a PJS program, so why not copy your code over to the HTML environment where it is allowed?

i think i mentioned this in another comment but the webpage environment is really annoying for any sort of serious coding due to the linter, which there's no way to avoid (unlike with pjs where i can just break out of the sandbox)

i'd have to host my code on some external cdn and link it in but that doesn't allow for easy development of code

Fun Fact: You can easily avoid Khan Academy's code checker in HTML projects by using 
```<script type>/* JS code here */</script>```
instead of
```<script>/* JS code here */</script>```
doing that also prevent Khan Academy from inserting their infinite loop detection function into your code.
that's a neat trick. still, i think the pjs environment is just more convenient

imo its easier to type `type` at the start of all your script tags rather than converting your entire program into hex code whenever you want to run it.

Anyways, I think I'm going to try making your music playing code run the webpage environment tomorrow.
i don't do that anymore; see musicy2
also i really don't have to do it this way. it's just the way i initially programmed it
i have a build script to automatically convert it for me and it's really easy to use
oh and also i don't have to use the ka editor lol. i can use a real text editor and have multiple files and stuff

yeah, but hardly any people will see your programs outside of KA unless you have a you tube channel or a bunch of followers on github or something.
Khan Academy is great because it advertises your prorgrams for you and hundreds of people get to see it on the hotlist.
no i mean my setup currently is that i write my code in a regular text editor and use my build script to compile it into the code for KA that i i just paste in
and for what it's worth i really don't care about people seeing my programs lol. i code for me not for clout

i'm only doing this on KA because i thought it was a neat challenge to do this in a limited sandbox environment, and i've always wanted to come back and make a game or something just for nostalgia's sake. it's been many years since i used ka actively

That was actually extremely simple.

https://www.khanacademy.org/computer-programming/musicy-2-but-not-against-the-guidelines/6701693761798144

Feel free to copy my little bit of code that runs the program in the webpage.
nice
So why don't you delete the program now? It's against the Guidelines.
if a guardian sees it fit to hide this from the hot list or whatever they'll do that. i really don't care about it being on the hot list or something
No, It's still against the Guidelines. "Straw Man"
not saying it isnt bud
Programs against the Guidelines are not allowed to be created.

that is not true.

"Projects that don’t meet the guidelines may be hidden from the "hot" list or from public view."

About off-topic, controversial, plagiarized etc. programs, but *not* disallowed functionality: "If a project or discussion post falls into one of the following disallowed criteria, a Guardian may hide it from the "hot" list and/or public view entirely. Learners who persistently break these rules may also get banned from community activity. Projects that spur discussions that distract from learning about computer programming and coding may also get hidden."

with respect to disallowed functionality it only says you shouldn't do it "to ensure that the ProcessingJS programs you create on Khan Academy will continue working in the future"

One of my programs that accessed the window object got hidden from public view, but this one didn't even when I reported it directly to a guardian. It just seems that the guardians do whatever they feel like.
it's cus i'm just built different.

Check out this topic on the support center
https://support.khanacademy.org/hc/en-us/community/posts/4421110679821-DOM-in-the-Processing-js-enviroment
your hACKING

I still don't understand how people make these awesome music programs! Great job! Too bad I can only see the code while it's loading though. How did you do that? I have a feeling that is has something to do with the 'hi's... 🤣

I'm not the creator, but I think I know how this works. Khan Academy has a JavaScript injector that they use to add in code like the infinite loop protector. There's some code in this program that changes what the injector injects to a bunch of hexadecimal codes which is then interpreted as actual code. That code then adds two properties (`.callAlerte` and `.removeEars`) to the `window` object. There's more code that then updates the editor to be what you see when the program loads. Since properties of the window object are retained even after the code is hidden, the program can call on them using `this`.

This is probably very confusing but I hope this makes some sense!

that's not how it works; `callAlerte` and `removeEars` aren't actually things it's just a funny joke i put in. the code in the live editor doesn't run

PJSCodeInjector.exec is the function that executes the code in the live editor; i replace it with my own code that contains an audio engine and stuff and then overwrites what's in the live editor so you see some in-jokes instead of nonsensical hex
if you want i could share the code
Ah, that's cool! Thank you for correcting me. Sure, I'd like to see how you did this.
Ok well i dunno if KA will let me post an offsite link so: go to my github @nim-ka and check out the kamusicy repository

Thank you! I managed to find it.

By the way, you can post offsite links by putting spaces in between certain parts of the link. So something like this:
https:// github. com/nim-ka/kamusicy
ah okay, thanks

FYI even when you space out a link it gets reported to the guardians.

Also I grabbed this programs code using the API and you can see it here
https://www.khanacademy.org/computer-programming/highly-illegal-code/5820212592033792

Okay, I didn't know that. Why are spaced out links detected but not hidden if normal links are?

Cool!
I don't know. That's just how Khan Academy's developers made it work apparently.
lol why did you go through the trouble of getting the program's code when you could just go to the link i said, it's public
It's disallowed functionality, flagged
nooooooo how could this happen to meeeee

idk how this could happen to you. You have been on Khan Academy for 10 years. You were one of the people who helped create Khan Academy's documentation. And you were one of the people who did review and testing for Khan Academy's programming courses before they were officially released.
yes those are things that are on my profile
geez it really has been 10 years hasnt it
well anyway yeah i did a lot of ka haxing too when i was little

First of all, you know you can put all your comments into one comment right? :P

I've been on KA for 11 years, but when I was little I didn't know enough JS to do any haxing.
yeah i know
most of my "haxing" was points botting

oop... thats pretty haxy.

The most haxy things I have ever done is access externals in a PJS program, and play mp3 files using base64 in an HTML program.
